Comment: The QP opening, which has a reputation for slow, positional play.
Kaufman goes with a Classical response.
Alekhine loved to develop Knights early.
Kaufman chooses to play a Queen's Gambit with colors reversed, in response.
The immediate QxP would give Alekhine 3 developed pieces to Kaufman's 0, but he chooses to postpone it.
The alternatives were ...P-QR3 or ...R-R1, neither of which appears significantly better than the text move.
Alekhine, with his advantage in development, wishes to open the board up further.
Kaufman captures the Pawn. 6...P-K3 may have been the safer alternative.
Alekhine goes in for the exchange of Queens.

Kaufman resigns. Alekhine threatens 9 N-B6 ch forking K and QR, and 9 NxP ch forking K and KR. 8...K-K1 is countered by 9 B-N5 ch forcing the King back to Q1 and allowing the "shakrukh". [Interposing with 9...B-Q2 doesn't help, as 10 BxB ch still forces the K back to Q1.] Well played by Alekhine.
